parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about sports psychology. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: The Mental Game
passage.content:
Dr. Carmen Ruiz watched as professional tennis player Alex Montenegro practiced his serve for the hundredth time that morning. As the team's sports psychologist, Carmen knew that Alex's recent losing streak had less to do with his physical technique and more to do with what was happening in his mind.

'The difference between good athletes and great ones isn't physical ability,' Carmen explained to the coaching staff later. 'At the professional level, everyone has exceptional skills. What separates champions from the rest is mental toughness and the ability to perform under pressure.'

Alex had been struggling with confidence since losing a crucial match three months earlier. The defeat had occurred in front of his home crowd, and the disappointment had created a cycle of negative thinking that affected his subsequent performances. 'When athletes start doubting themselves, it becomes a self-fulfilling prophecy,' Carmen noted.

Carmen's approach focused on rebuilding Alex's mental framework rather than changing his playing style. Through visualization exercises, Alex learned to mentally rehearse successful performances before stepping onto the court. 'Mental rehearsal is like physical practice,' Carmen explained. 'The brain doesn't distinguish between vividly imagined experiences and real ones.'

Breathing techniques formed another crucial component of Alex's mental training. During high-pressure moments, controlled breathing helped regulate his nervous system and maintain focus. 'When your heart rate spikes during competition, proper breathing can be the difference between making a brilliant shot and choking,' Carmen observed.

The transformation didn't happen overnight. Alex initially resisted the psychological training, preferring to focus on technical improvements. 'Many athletes think sports psychology is only for players who are struggling,' Carmen noted. 'But the most successful athletes are usually the ones who take mental training seriously.'

After six months of consistent mental training, Alex's performance had improved dramatically. He'd won two tournaments and reached the finals of three others. More importantly, he'd developed tools to handle pressure and setbacks more effectively.

'Physical training develops your body,' Carmen concluded. 'Mental training develops your ability to use that body when it matters most. Both are essential for peak performance, but many athletes neglect the psychological component until it's too late.'

questions.text: According to Dr. Ruiz, what distinguishes great athletes from good ones?
options: A) Superior physical conditioning and training.
B) Better coaching and technical instruction.
C) Mental toughness and pressure performance.
D) More natural talent and athletic ability.

questions.text: What caused Alex Montenegro's recent performance problems?
options: A) A physical injury that hadn't healed properly.
B) Loss of confidence after a disappointing defeat.
C) Conflicts with his coaching team.
D) Technical flaws in his playing technique.

questions.text: How does Carmen explain the effectiveness of visualization exercises?
options: A) They help athletes identify technical weaknesses.
B) They improve physical coordination and timing.
C) The brain treats imagined experiences like real ones.
D) They reduce the time needed for physical practice.

questions.text: What role do breathing techniques play in Alex's training?
options: A) They improve his physical endurance.
B) They help him maintain focus under pressure.
C) They prevent muscle tension and injuries.
D) They enhance his reaction time during play.

questions.text: How did Alex initially respond to psychological training?
options: A) He was enthusiastic and committed to the process.
B) He was skeptical and preferred technical improvements.
C) He found it too difficult and wanted to quit.
D) He was concerned about the time commitment required.

questions.text: What does Carmen suggest about when athletes should begin mental training?
options: A) Only after experiencing performance problems.
B) When they reach professional level competition.
C) Before problems develop, as part of regular training.
D) After mastering all the technical aspects of their sport.

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about cultural festivals around the world. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: Celebrating Cultural Heritage
passage.content:
Traditional festivals serve as vital connections between past and present, preserving cultural identity while adapting to modern circumstances. These celebrations offer communities opportunities to strengthen social bonds and share their heritage with the world.

[7]

The economic impact of cultural festivals extends far beyond the event itself. Local businesses, hotels, restaurants, and artisans often see significant increases in revenue during festival periods.

[8]

However, the commercialization of traditional festivals raises important questions about authenticity. Some communities worry that external pressures to attract tourists may dilute the original meaning and practices of their celebrations.

[9]

Technology plays an increasingly important role in modern festival organization. Social media platforms help spread awareness globally, while digital ticketing and crowd management systems ensure safer, more efficient events.

[10]

Environmental considerations have become crucial factors in festival planning. Many organizers now prioritize sustainable practices, from waste reduction to using renewable energy sources for large-scale events.

[11]

The intergenerational transfer of cultural knowledge remains one of the most valuable aspects of traditional festivals. Older community members pass down customs, stories, and skills to younger generations through direct participation.

[12]

As globalization continues to reshape societies, cultural festivals provide essential anchors that help communities maintain their unique identities while engaging with the broader world.

paragraphs.text: Many festivals now attract international visitors, transforming local celebrations into global cultural exchanges.
This economic boost can be particularly important for rural or economically disadvantaged communities.
Striking the right balance between preserving tradition and embracing innovation requires careful consideration and community input.
These digital tools have made festivals more accessible to people with disabilities and those unable to attend in person.
These environmentally conscious approaches often inspire festival-goers to adopt more sustainable practices in their daily lives.
This living transmission of culture cannot be replicated through books or digital media alone.
Some festivals have been celebrated continuously for hundreds or even thousands of years, adapting to changing times while maintaining their core significance.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about four people who work in health and wellness fields. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Dr. Patricia Santos - Nutritionist
people.text: I help people develop sustainable eating habits that support their health goals without creating unrealistic restrictions. Many clients come to me after trying multiple fad diets that promised quick results but ultimately failed. My approach focuses on understanding individual nutritional needs, lifestyle factors, and food preferences rather than applying one-size-fits-all solutions. I work closely with people who have medical conditions like diabetes or heart disease, where proper nutrition is crucial for managing their health. Education is a key part of my practice - I teach clients how to read food labels, plan balanced meals, and make informed choices when eating out. The most rewarding aspect of my work is seeing clients develop confidence in their relationship with food.

people.name: Marcus Rivera - Physical Therapist
people.text: I specialize in helping people recover from injuries and improve their physical function through targeted exercises and manual therapy techniques. My patients range from professional athletes recovering from sports injuries to elderly individuals working to maintain their independence. Each treatment plan is customized based on the person's specific condition, goals, and physical capabilities. Pain management is often a primary concern, but I focus on addressing the underlying causes rather than just masking symptoms. I collaborate frequently with doctors, surgeons, and other healthcare professionals to ensure comprehensive care. The field requires continuous learning as new treatment techniques and technologies are constantly being developed.

people.name: Dr. Lisa Chen - Sleep Specialist
people.text: I diagnose and treat sleep disorders that affect millions of people worldwide. Poor sleep quality impacts every aspect of health, from immune function to mental well-being, yet many people don't realize their health problems stem from sleep issues. My work involves conducting sleep studies in specialized laboratories where we monitor patients' brain waves, breathing patterns, and body movements throughout the night. Treatment approaches vary widely - some patients need medical devices like CPAP machines, while others benefit from behavioral therapy or lifestyle modifications. I often educate patients about sleep hygiene practices that can dramatically improve their rest quality. The challenge is convincing people that sleep is not a luxury but a medical necessity.

people.name: Roberto Martinez - Mental Health Counselor
people.text: I provide therapy and support for people dealing with anxiety, depression, trauma, and relationship issues. Mental health stigma remains a significant barrier - many people delay seeking help until their problems become severe. My therapeutic approach emphasizes building coping skills and helping clients understand patterns in their thoughts and behaviors. Group therapy sessions can be particularly effective because participants realize they're not alone in their struggles. I work with individuals of all ages, from teenagers dealing with academic pressure to adults navigating major life transitions. Self-care is essential in this field because absorbing others' emotional pain can be mentally and physically exhausting.
